reviewText: This is a great movie.  The Gershwin trust may object to the performing version - it includes dialogue, which the opera version doesn't .  But that should not be a valid reason to keep this movie off the market any more than the fact that Poitier, Dandridge and Diahann Carroll don't sing for themselves.  Lots of movies have dubbed voices, and we, the audience, don't care.  What matters here is the incredible acting and pacing.  It is indeed Sammy Davis' best performance, and his scene with Pearl Bailey still rattles around in my brain, and I haven't seen it for years.There were two versions of the film shown in theatres.  One had the center of "I've got plenty of nothin'" omitted and left out "My man's gone now."  (A cut I cannot imagine making since the Serena was perfect.)  A DVD version offered by another company (quite illegally, I'm sure) is in terrible color (all orangy) and is the short version - roughly 2 hours.  The whole thing should run around 2hours 30 minutes.  So I can only hope that the movie studio, lawyers and heirs are working on a solution to the hold-up, because we are the ones being held-up.The movie industry makes so few movies like this now, that it would be wonderful to see it released on DVD so they could see how much potential a good plot, great acting and music can actually provide.  And yes, hurry, so Poitier, Peters, Carroll, Previn and a few others can provide commentary.  Davis, Bailey and Dandridge are already gone.I think the Gershwin Trust should be invited to write a "Why we won't release Porgy and Bess on DVD" for Amazon, so we can all complain right back.  If I had their address, my letter would be sane but very strong.  Release This Film.Apparently, after writing the above, it was stated by the heirs that they objected to Andre Previn's reorchestration of at least parts of the score.  My answer is this:Did Rodgers and Hammerstein object when they reorchestrated King and I for the screen (or cut numbers and transposed them)?  No.Do actors object when their earlier performances are still aired with the idea that "they are as good as they should be"?  No, because they were as good as they could be.It should be noted that the published piano-vocal score uses the iconic image of the movie poster for its cover.  If I were the Premingers, i might insist that they stop using it or release the movie.Premingers and the movie industry are allowing the Gershwin heirs too much leverage.  They were paid for the rights, and they should not have reverted back to the Gershwins so quickly.  Release it in a good print for two months and see how many people buy it.  I will, for sure, and a few for presents.
summary: Some reasons that aren't good enough.

This is a great film and it should be available. But there is no question tht the arrangements by Andre Previn deviate substantially from the original Gershwin score.

reviewText: Okay folks, I actually saw this movie last night on a European DVD with not-so-hot but watchable picture quality, so here goes.First of all, it's not for all tastes. Very much a filmed stage play. Pearl Bailey and a few others aside, the singing voices are dubbed.It's a bit jarring to see Sir Sid (Poitier, that is) playing a poor crippled beggar in comparison to his usual urbane and sophisticated roles (he did not want to do this film because of the racial stereotyping-more on that in a minute). He tries to put in as much of the Sir Sid dignity and articulation as possible, so it's strange to hear him "sing" (in dubbed form) the P&B; songs in dialect that is not his speaking voice or style.The late great Dorothy Dandridge makes a decent Bess. She wears the hell out of the split red skirt. I was moved by her and Sir Sid's performance of "Bess You Is My Woman Now" and "I Loves You Porgy." Brock Peters is well cast as Crown and Sammy Davis Jr. almost literally leaps from the screen as Sportin' Life. He really wanted to do this film and the excitement he brings to the role is infectious. He sets the screen on fire during "It Aint Necessarily So." Dihann Carroll is suitable restrained as Serena.I grew up in Charleston and know the relatives of Samuel Smalls (the real life crippled beggar who inspired DuBose Heyward to write the story), so P&B; in its various albums and presentations means a lot to me. Those familiar with Black Charleston's culture and history will be charmed by the inside cultural references such as the Crab man and Stawberry lady, the Jenkins Orphanage Band (the child musicians of the 1920s-a facsimile of them appears in the parade segment) and the Mosquito fleet (a legendary group of black fisherman in the area).P&B; pruists may dislike the fact that there is added dialogue to the film and the traditional songs and story of P&B; are done out of standard sequence, but there are always concessions to be made when popular books and operas are committed to film. It is said this is why the Gershwin and Heyward families withdrew the film from public view.Regarding the alleged stereotyping and racism. Admittedly, the opening crap shooting scene grated on my nerves (the idea of this being so acceptable in the Black community that a man's wife gives him permission to shoot craps is a bit much) and seeing the dignified Sir Sid partake in this is outlandish. But that aside, while it is true that crap shooting, alcoholism, drug abuse, prostitution, dialect speaking, et. al. did and does exist in Black Charleston (as well as other areas and ethnic groups), the problem that Poitier and many other blacks have with P&B; is that to too many people outside of Black America, this is all that's known of us African-Americans to people who don't interact with us personally, and it becomes a hindrance to blacks who try to advance to higher positions. This was especially true when this film came out in 1959 when Blacks were just beginning to integrate into mainstream opportunities.With that said, one reviewer noted the often gritty subject matter. This film handles these matters in fairly good taste an there is no profanity or graphic sexuality to be found (Dandridge as Bess turns her back to the camera when she snorts the "Happy dust" (cocaine).On the whole, I personally like this version and I rank it in the same class as "Carmen Jones," Cabin in the Sky", "Stormy Weather," and in some ways the recent "Dreamgirls" as excellent examples African-American musical talent on film. However, those who are not used to "Folk Operas" and muscials where there the dialogue is mostly sung may not like this, or the fact that there only appear to be two sets of scenery (The tenament and the picnic grounds) in the whole film. But in fairness, while I personally like this, I'll admit it's not for all tastes.
summary: I actually saw it last night, and......

reviewText: Sidney Poitier, Dorothy Dandridge, Sammy Davis Jr., Brock Peters, Pearl Bailey, Diahann Carroll, Ivan Dixon, Maya Angelou  and on and on and on.  Shantytown, a deep south "colored" fishing ghetto and all its inhabitants are musically portrayed in this classic movie.  No contemporary remake (cinematic or stage) can capture the ambience or flavor of the performances in this 1959 classic.  The songs; SUMMERTIME, I'M ON MY WAY, IT AIN'T NECESSARILY SO, BESS YOU IS MY WOMAN NOW, etc., echo in one's memory.  This all-star AA ensemble will enthrall you.Poitier (Porgy), without legs below the knees and forced to use his arms and hands for mobility, plays the protagonist against Brock Peters' (Crown) "whole man" antagonist in the struggle for Dorothy Dandridge (Bess), the physical but morally "scarlet-lettered" beauty of the community.  Sammy Davis Jr. (Sportin' Life) the street-wise city slicker, like a devil on her shoulder, is always there to tempt Bess with dreams of New York City (where her beauty can be "appreciated"), and the "feel-good" drug heroin.  Brock, in jail because of his violent temper and the desire to posess Bess, escapes and lurks in the background as Portier becomes sweet on Bess and sways her to the real things in life, like community and love.  Their confrontation is inevitable.The struggle between good and evil is obvious as is the desire of the characters to overcome life's adversities.  Set in a not so unreal, prejudicial era (circa 1930's), the characters manage to "live" their meager lives with hope and in the belief of God.  However, Porgy and Bess is a story of belief in one's self.  It is set to some of the most stirring music ever produced.  The portrayal of life's condition reverberates in the music, but especially in the verses of this song: "It ain't necessarily so, the things you are liable to read in the bible, it ain't necessarily so".
Title: N/A

reviewText: The film of Porgy and Bess did not appear in the UK until 1962.  Its release had to wait for 'South Pacific's' five year run to end, as it needed that particular theatre for it to be seen in TODD-AO.  Sadly, I saw the film once it went on 'general release' where it was shown on a small screen and with 'restricted stereophonic sound'.  To be honest, I did not enjoy the film's production at all.  I found it 'claustrophobic' and the colour to be irritating ..... BUT ...... the performances of both Sydney Poitier and Dorothy Dandridge were spectacular.  I had seen and loved 'Carmen Jones' and found Ms Dandridge to be the PERFECT Carmen.  Her versitility as an actress is WITHOUT QUESTION ... just watch her in 'Bright Road' and 'Carmen Jones' to see this!  Her death was a great tragedy as I believe that she would have developed into a wonderful actress and taken her place with the greats.Since 1962, I have seen 'Porgy and Bess - the opera and the musical' a number of times.  I especially enjoyed the musical stage version at the Savoy Theatre in London a few years back where non-operatic singers played the major roles. I would love to see it presented on Broadway as I believe this would 'open up' this BRILLIANT OPERA to more people and certainly to a new generation.  Gerswin's music is a joy.  One is constantly hearing about 'American music' etc etc - this is truly an American story with glorious American music.Regarding the film: naturally there are faults and it is probably a product of its time - but - this should not mean that it is 'lost' to us.  The film could be released on DVD along with a discussion where those 'in favour of it' and those 'against it' could express their views - not being able to see it is a tragic loss to those of us that LOVE the story, LOVE the music and LOVE the performances given here.I am PROUD to add my voice to those who request the film's release on DVD.Thanks for your time.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I saw this movie many years ago and am about to see a production of it in Los Angeles.  The movie is not necessarily so --- but it is as close a version on screen that we have.  And there are some amazing performances, especially Sammy Davis Jr.  The American Musical is in dire need of being made available to the public.  And while this is actually an opera and not a musical per se, it is part of the American musical experience.  Please urge whoever is responsbile to issue a DVD of this movie so that people of all generations can see, hear and appreciate the genius that was Gershwin.

reviewText: This is truly the definitive version! It is meticulously filmed and the music is "to die for"! Yes, the major characters are dubbed but who wasn't back then? It has stellar performances from Mr. Poitier, Miss Bailey, Mr. Davis and the brilliant and sublime Miss Dorothy Dandridge! Let's hope all parties concerned will come to an agreement soon and this magnificent work of art will be available in it's entirety for future generations to see and hear. WE NEED THE DVD!!!

reviewText: You have to be impressed with a film that can make the American Film Institute's list of America's Greatest Love Stories when the only place you can see it is in the Library of Congress.  The Gershwin family was very unhappy with this 1959 film version of this most American opera (yes, opera), feeling that producer Samuel Goldwyn had made a major mistake in firing Rouben Mamoulian, the director of the original stage version in 1935 and the film's original director, and in glamorizing the story.  The last time "Porgy and Bess" was seen was on television in the mid-1960's, at which point the Gershwin's withdrew all copies of the film.The music, of course, is by George Gershwin, with the text by Du Bose Heyward and Ira Gershwin after the drama "Porgy" by Du Bose and Dorothy Heyward.  The show was first produced in 1935 with a notable revival in 1953 with Leontyne Price and William Warfield.  The film stars Sidney Portier as Porgy (his singing was dubbed by opera singer Bobby McFerrin, Sr.), Dorothyy Dandridge as Bess, with Sammy Davis Jr. as Sportin' Life, Pearl Bailey as Maria, Brock Peters as Crown, and Diahann Carroll as Clara.  Clearly, we are talking an incredibly talented cast of performers which should have made this film a benchmark in the history of American films featuring African-American actors and actresses; I would argue that not until "The Color Purple" have we seen anything comparable.  However, we are talking Hollywood, so we are not overly surprised.The story is essentially a pair of competing love triangles set in Catfish Row in Charleston, South Carolina: The cripple Porgy (baritone) loves Bess (soprano), but she has left him for Crown (bass).  After Crown murders a gambler in a quarrel, Porgy takes Bess in, despite the offer of Sportin' Life (tenor) to take her to New York.  Bess bounches back and forth between Porgy and Crown until the former murders the later, and then she runs off to the big city with Sportin' Life, leaving Porgy to head after her once again.Best Lines: Obviously from the songs (1) "Summertime and the livin' is easy"; (2) "It ain't necessarily so" and (3) "Bess, you is my woman now."If you like "Porgy and Bess," then check out these other films on AFI's list: #67 "A Streetcar Named Desire."  Why?  Because it is another operatic love story that would make a great opera (didn't somebody already do that?).
summary: AFI's Great Love Stories: #92 Porgy and Bess
Title: N/A

reviewText: I believe Porgy and Bess was the first movie I ever saw, when I was about three years old, in a movie theater in the Queensbridge Projects, Long Island City, NY.  (My second movie was West Side Story.) Porgy and Bess has only appeared a couple of times on TV, and a few times in special screenings.  The last screening was probably the year 2000 at either Brooklyn College or the Long Island University campus in Brooklyn, which had a panel discussion afterward over the film's supposed racism and other issues.I'm not often one to knock political correctness, but please, knock your PC fears aside and release this movie!  It's inspiring, fun, glorious, exciting, etc., etc., with wonderful performances by Dorothy Dandridge (Bess), Sammy Davis, Jr. (who dances up a storm as Sportin' Life), Pearl Bailey (Maria), and Brock Peters (outstanding as Crown).  I've only thought this recently: Sidney Poitier, although he does an admirable job, is miscast as Porgy.  Porgy is a good soul, but Poitier is too refined for an uneducated street beggar; Poitier's Porgy, I imagine, went to college to study law and had a bad accident which devastated his life.  Too bad Brock Peters couldn't play two roles at once.The movie even has a scene, which I think is in the play Porgy but isn't in the opera, where Serena offers to take an orphaned baby given to Bess, and Bess refuses.I love P&B;'s verve, spirituality, fun, and grand Gershwin music.  I've seen the full operatic version on Broadway (by the Houston Grand Opera) in the 1970s and at the Metropolitan Opera House in the 1980s or 90s, as well as the truncated New York City Opera version in 2000.  Now please do us Porgy and Bess fans a favor and release this movie on DVD, too!  (I'd prefer it on VHS, but people aren't making those anymore, are they?)BTW, I am an African-American woman with a love of musical theater and American opera.
summary: Oh, oh, ohhhhhhhh--I want it, I want it!

reviewText: As everyone has previously said everything I could say, I only wanted to add this: in 1973 or so, I can vividly recollect our local Channel 44 (KBHK) showing this film and during the station breaks informing the viewers that, because of something having to do with the NAACP, they would no longer be able to EVER show the film again. (I don't know the details, but I vividly recall THAT, as I sat curled up in a chair about 2' from the TV and chowing down popcorn. I spent many of my early adolescent years watching TV all Saturday...*sigh*) I can say this: I loved the movie enough that I went to our local library and checked out the 3-LP recorded version, and have a sweetly poignant memory of the music and my life at that age...OK, enough already! But I have been eternally [upset] that this movie became completely unavailable to us Gershwin fansfor the following 25 years! As I recall, that same day Channel 44 also showed "A Star is Born" !)Anyway, less us awl put sum preshuh on the Goishwins or whoevah is responsible fuh owa not bein able ta see dis heah fillum.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This work of art has not been released on DVD because someone other than the artist has not wanted it released (...). This was a great film and reflects not only Gershwin's talent, but that of terrific actors, director, etc. It was a cultural "happening" and belongs in the public domain if the estate does not want to market it.

reviewText: I went to see "Porgy and Bess" when it premiered in Los Angeles almost 50 years ago in 1959.  Many "uppity negroes" were up in arms because of the stereotypical portrayal of Blacks in the film, but I didn't care because I went soley to see Dorothy Dandridge, Hollywood's beautiful (and only) black screen goddess. You see, I had developed what turned out to be lifelong crush on La Dandridge while watching "Bright Road" and "Carmen Jones" in 1953 and 1954. Though I was only 9 years old at the time, I am still in love with DD and still captivated by her timeless beauty. I will turn 64 in December.  Sadly, this film is Dorothy's last appearance on the big screen prior to her untimely death (age 42) in 1965.Of course, I am very excited about the DVD release of this Black Classic and trust the film will be fully restored and re-mastered -  and include a comprehensive Special Features detailing the struggle to get this project on track.  Interviews with Sidney Poiter and Diahann Carroll, the only surviving stars, is imperative.I've seen a bootleg copy "Porgy and Bess" and the color is awful. I still can't believe the Gershwins have okayed this project after refusing to allow the movie to be shown after all these years. The Amazon ad shows the DVD was released in 2002. What gives? I've never seen it. Seeing is believing, so I'll just keep wishing and hoping...and waiting!Thanks for answering my prayers.Samuel Augustus Jennings
Title: N/A

reviewText: I haven't seen this movie since the 70s; and I miss it; I think it's a shame that they don't show it on TV much less on video; All I know is that I used to watch on Channel 11 in NYC, all the time, then all of a sudden, they stopped putting it on TV; Such a shame;Ok, there are stereotypes in here,but, remembering what you saw as a child, you just want to see it again; Especially since it is one of the very few films that Dorothy Dandridge starred in and u just cannot see; I think it's a shame;

reviewText: As of January, 2005, PORGY AND BESS is still tied up in estate shenanigans.  Hopefully, when its just the lawyers and not the heirs calling the shots, things might change.  It has been said that the Goldwyns are keeping the elements in good shape.  I hope so. My vote for any commentary on a DVD release would be Maya Angelou.  A veteran of both the film and the Breen-Davis tour, she would speak eloquently and lovingly of the piece.  Perhaps Brock Peters would, too.  The film is not his only exposure to the work, either.  Andre Previn's still around. They could fill us in on all the Mamoulian/pre-fire history of the film once and for all.  That would be fun.A few other wishes for the DVD-the complete Overture as heard on the soundtrack album, the album track of I GOT PLENTY O' NUTTIN' which is better than the track used in the film, lots of costume and set design renderings in the bonus section.  That set has been criticized as too outlandish, but since you have to look at it for over two hours and not get bored with it, it works for me. Among all the other players mentioned in various posts, no one's mentioned Ruth Attaway's Serena. She's wonderful.
Title: N/A
